>If your directory has a lot of subdirectories and/or small files, there may be a huge difference between logical and actual size of directory.

https://stackoverflow.com/a/19596456

---

Unfortunately, Android system's APP manager only use logical size to calculate, so users can be easily warned of the storage is getting full due to ZeroNet. As I said before, we need to archive zites into several zip files in client side.

Also, we need to add support for zite owner to archive many inactive users' files into zip, because zites are getting bigger and containing more and more small files ( 5000+ for ZeroMe user registry hub, 2000+ for ZeroTalk/NewGFWTalk/popular hubs) which makes new ZeroNet users' initial zite download very slow and results in bad new users' experience.

> [nofish](#comment_182_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj): I will test if zip/sqlite/bsddb suitable for this. I did some similar benchmarks last year: https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/463#issuecomment-220978182

zip has performance issue of appending files into archive ( zip file getting more and more bigger since no overwrite support just append, 6 times slower than writing directly to OS filesystem ). sqlite is slower in security mode than in speed mode.
So IMO, we may just avoid writing to zip/sqlite/bsddb. As I said before, we can do this via simple strategy:
- Add support for zite owner to archive many inactive users' files into zip or something (e.g. 11.zip 12.zip ... 1A.zip 1B.zip ... 1Z.zip for different first 2 char of user addresses) via hidden menu ( auto-backup before archiving and publishing )
- On the zite user side, read files outside zip first, if can not find the file, find it inside the zip
- If need to write, write directly to OS filesystem. Never write into zip

> [nofish](#comment_184_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj):
> I have added more info and problems here: https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/98#issuecomment-283525022

I don't think we have problem 1 you said in /issues/98 if we do it via strategy I said.
Zite owner archives users' files into 11.zip 12.zip ... 1A.zip 1B.zip ... 1Z.zip by the user addresses rather than by time-stamped zip. It would be very quick to find a specified user's file, and just need to read from only one zip.
If an archived user starts posting again, we writes his/her **_whole_** file outside the zip, directly to OS filesystem. Thus, we just ignore his/her old file in zip. On the zite user side, reading is fast, writing is fast, everything works well without any problem.
Only thing need to notice, though very tiny, is zite owner need to unpack all zip before monthly archiving (repack), which makes archiving a little slow. But it's obviously not a big problem because zite owner is only one person ( VS thousands of users ) and only need to do it once a month!

> [nofish](#comment_185_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj): I think time stamping would be much better

My idea to optimize Solution 1:
zite owner builds a db indexing all archives, let user side quickly knows which archives have the specified user's files. Zite owner updates the db when zite owner monthly archiving. I think it would speed up reading.

- Thanks to Peer2Peer technology and decentralized structure,  a site owner does not need to be online to watch and maintain sites now and then in case of sites cracked or DDOS-ed ( It would be nice if you can find a humorous GIF showing what is DDOS ). This is important because being online long-time and frequently is not possible for many site owners and is dangerous for someone who want to keep highly anonymous.
- Centralizing is the friend of censorship. We can see censorship by commercial companies and evil governments. Methods of censorship are not only deleting or forbidding , but also DDOS.

A good example: [According Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voat), in 2015, Voat, a website has been labelled as an alternative to Reddit with a focus on freedom of expression, experienced large influx of new users after Reddit banned five of its subreddits for harassment—the largest of which had around 150,000 subscribers. The large influx temporarily overloaded the site, causing downtime. During this time, Voat had both its web hosting and PayPal accounts closed without warning. Its German web host cited "politically incorrect" content on the site and distrust of Voat as the cause since Germany has strict rules for hosting services. The website continued to accept donations in Bitcoin, and was able to continue functioning, as it had moved to a different hosting provider. But the website continued to experience downtime due to an ongoing distributed denial of service (DDOS) attack, rendering the 700,000 unique visitors unable to access the site.

A month later, following the dismissal of a popular administrator on Reddit, another influx of Reddit members registered with Voat, leading to traffic which again caused Voat to experience downtime.

So we have [ZeroVoat](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1J1c7eML6uMwDU4uiKbKRxoqxGP6WMFMvb) (  show demo ), decentralized clone of Voat. No downtime if there is at least one peer seeding the site. Compared with the original centralized one, more influxes of users means more peers, and more stable and fast it will be.
